content.description: This route really has just one tough and committing move.  In addition it is above some protruding rocks (I've done a little bit to flatten the landing) which can be fully covered with a standard pad. If you look inside the large pocket you'll see crystals and garnets.
content.location: Just above the only protruding rocks at the base of this boulder.

content.description:
This is the route that really makes The Dark Crystal Boulder unique! A series of pockets that traverse this side of the boulder and it's slightly overhanging angle combine for an excellent set of natural features. 

  Start on the right side at a good pocket. Traverse the pods left then top out. Your feet will never be more then 3ft of the ground.  

  The sit start (either continuing into Podlings or topping out straight up) is still a project.
content.location: Left and around the corner of Skeksis

content.description: The crux is figuring out how to use the side pull. Clever moves will unlock the secret and lead to an easy top out.
content.location: This problem is just left of the birch that separates this from "Landstrider"

content.description: Unique sequence and interesting moves make this a solid 3 star route. Once covered in "potato chip" lichen and after cleaning revealed 3 crucial finger pockets.
content.location: It is found just as you turn right at the "far striped tree". Walk off easily to the trail.

content.description: The far left route on the tall face of the Dark Crystal Boulder, Bloody Chin starts on a cool crystally pocket. Work up left, eventually using a sloping corner and/or small crimp, and make a committing move to the lip. Top out and avoid using the tree.

This boulder seems to be a bit of an anomaly.  Of all the other boulders it has a unique set of features with flat, open landings under all but one route.  It also has a flat (very low angle) top with an easy walk off the back.  The only draw back is it's mossy top which causes it to "sweat" for some time after a good rain.
